conversation.content: [bitter] Funny coincidence. [pause]

[withdrawn] Well, um, I've been watching you train for, [hesitantly], three months now and, like, [slowly], there's something I need to tell you before, [shaky voice], we continue with these sessions. [sigh]
[cynical] Yeah, um, let me guess, you know, [frustrated], you've figured out I make my living pretending to be, [trailing off], someone more successful than I'll ever actually be...
[defensive] It's not about your work, [anxious], it's about why you look exactly like, [whispering], my son who became famous doing the very moves I'm, [very quietly], teaching you now.

[shocked] Wait, um, are you saying that, I mean, [confused], the reason I can pass for Jason Chen is because, well, [trembling], you think we're somehow related or, like, [loudly], what exactly are you implying here?
[regretful] Not implying anything.
[angry] So, um, you're telling me that, er, [bitterly], thirty-two years of wondering why I looked nothing like my adoptive parents comes down to this? [laugh]
The adoption agency promised they'd place you, [crying while speaking], far from California where no one would, [monotone], make the connection between you and the son I, [ashamed], kept.
[furious] Well, jokes on them, I mean, [sarcastic], I moved here specifically to capitalize on looking exactly like your golden child. [cough]

[apologetic] Every technique I taught him, [very sad], every stance and philosophy that made him famous, [whispering loudly], I've been teaching you these past months without, [clearing throat], realizing I was giving you your birthright.
Um, my birthright was, like, [upset], supposedly being loved equally but instead getting, well, [coldly], tossed away while you kept the one you, [passionately], thought had more potential, right?
[desperate] It wasn't about potential, [quickly], it was about your mother's family threatening to, [stern], take both of you if I didn't, [nervously], let them place one for adoption. [long pause]
[exhausted] All these years I've been, [hollow], copying his moves from movies.
[warm] Those moves were originally meant for, [empathetically], both of you to learn together as brothers.

[disgusted] You know, um, the real kicker is that, I mean, [mocking], I'm actually better at the techniques than he is because, well, [speeding up], I had to study every micro-movement to survive as his shadow.
That dedication and precision, [proudly], those are traits you inherited from, [chuckle], our family's bloodline.
Don't say our.
Please let me explain. [gasp]
[resigned] The only thing that matters now is whether you'll, [formal], keep teaching me or not.
[determined] I'll teach you everything I, [hopeful], should have taught you thirty years ago if you'll, [pleading], let me. [sniffle]

scenario: A celebrity lookalike discovers their martial arts instructor is actually their biological parent who gave them up for adoption, explaining their uncanny resemblance to a famous action star who is the instructor's other child.
